source: ## Analyze A/B Test Results You may either submit your notebook through the workspace here, or you may work from your local machine and submit through the next page. Either way assure that your code passes the project [RUBRIC](https://review.udacity.com/#!/projects/37e27304-ad47-4eb0-a1ab-8c12f60e43d0/rubric). **Please save regularly.** This project will assure you have mastered the subjects covered in the statistics lessons. The hope is to have this project be as comprehensive of these topics as possible. Good luck! ## Table of Contents - [Introduction](#intro) - [Part I - Probability](#probability) - [Part II - A/B Test](#ab_test) - [Part III - Regression](#regression) ### Introduction A/B tests are very commonly performed by data analysts and data scientists. It is important that you get some practice working with the difficulties of these For this project, you will be working to understand the results of an A/B test run by an e-commerce website. Your goal is to work through this notebook to help the company understand if they should implement the new page, keep the old page, or perhaps run the experiment longer to make their decision. **As you work through this notebook, follow along in the classroom and answer the corresponding quiz questions associated with each question.** The labels for each classroom concept are provided for each question. This will assure you are on the right track as you work through the project, and you can feel more confident in your final submission meeting the criteria. As a final check, assure you meet all the criteria on the [RUBRIC](https://review.udacity.com/#!/projects/37e27304-ad47-4eb0-a1ab-8c12f60e43d0/rubric). #### Part I - Probability To get started, let's import our libraries.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
#We are setting the seed to assure you get the same answers on quizzes as we set up
random.seed(42)

`1.` Now, read in the `ab_data.csv` data. Store it in `df`.  **Use your dataframe to answer the questions in Quiz 1 of the classroom.**

a. Read in the dataset and take a look at the top few rows here:
df = pd.read_csv("ab_data.csv")

text/html:
user_id timestamp group landing_page converted
0 851104 2017-01-21 22:11:48.556739 control old_page 0
1 804228 2017-01-12 08:01:45.159739 control old_page 0
2 661590 2017-01-11 16:55:06.154213 treatment new_page 0
3 853541 2017-01-08 18:28:03.143765 treatment new_page 0
4 864975 2017-01-21 01:52:26.210827 control old_page 1

source: df.head()
b. Use the cell below to find the number of rows in the dataset.

outputs.name: stdout
text: number of rows in the dataset is 294478

source: number_rows = df.shape[0]
print("number of rows in the dataset is", number_rows)
c. The number of unique users in the dataset.

outputs.name: stdout
text: number of unique users in the dataset is 290584

source: number_unique_users = df["user_id"].nunique()
print("number of unique users in the dataset is", number_unique_users)
d. The proportion of users converted.
# drop duplicates (Do not need)
# df.drop_duplicates(subset=['user_id'],keep='first',inplace=True)
proportion_users_converted = df[df["converted"]==1].shape[0] / df.shape[0]
print("proportion of users converted is", proportion_users_converted)
e. The number of times the `new_page` and `treatment` don't match.
df[(df["group"]=="treatment") & (df["landing_page"]=="old_page")].shape[0] + df[(df["group"]=="control") & (df["landing_page"]=="new_page")].shape[0]
f. Do any of the rows have missing values?

text/plain:
user_id         0
timestamp       0
group           0
landing_page    0
converted       0
dtype: int64

source: df.isnull().sum()

`2.` For the rows where **treatment** does not match with **new_page** or **control** does not match with **old_page**, we cannot be sure if this row truly received the new or old page.  Use **Quiz 2** in the classroom to figure out how we should handle these rows.  

a. Now use the answer to the quiz to create a new dataset that meets the specifications from the quiz.  Store your new dataframe in **df2**.
df2 = df.copy()
df2 = df[((df2['group'] == 'treatment') == (df2['landing_page'] == 'new_page')) != False]
# Double Check all of the correct rows were removed - this should be 0
df2[((df2['group'] == 'treatment') == (df2['landing_page'] == 'new_page')) == False].shape[0]
`3.` Use **df2** and the cells below to answer questions for **Quiz3** in the classroom.
a. How many unique **user_id**s are in **df2**?

outputs.name: stdout
text: number of unique users in the dataset df2 is 290584

source: number_unique_users2 = df2["user_id"].nunique()
print("number of unique users in the dataset df2 is", number_unique_users2)
b. There is one **user_id** repeated in **df2**.  What is it?

text/html:
user_id timestamp group landing_page converted
2893 773192 2017-01-14 02:55:59.590927 treatment new_page 0

source: df2[df2.duplicated("user_id")]
c. What is the row information for the repeat **user_id**?

text/html:
user_id timestamp group landing_page converted
1899 773192 2017-01-09 05:37:58.781806 treatment new_page 0
2893 773192 2017-01-14 02:55:59.590927 treatment new_page 0

source: df2.drop(labels = 2893, inplace=True)

`4.` Use **df2** in the cells below to answer the quiz questions related to **Quiz 4** in the classroom.

a. What is the probability of an individual converting regardless of the page they receive?

outputs.name: stdout
text: proportion of an individual converting is 0.11959708724499628

source: proportion_users_converted2 = df2[df2["converted"]==1].shape[0] / df2.shape[0]
print("proportion of an individual converting is", proportion_users_converted2)
b. Given that an individual was in the `control` group, what is the probability they converted?
proportion_users_converted3 = df2[(df2["group"]=="control") & (df2["converted"]==1)].shape[0] / df2[df2["group"]=="control"].shape[0]
print("probability they converted is", proportion_users_converted3)
c. Given that an individual was in the `treatment` group, what is the probability they converted?
proportion_users_converted4 = df2[(df2["group"]=="treatment") & (df2["converted"]==1)].shape[0] / df2[df2["group"]=="treatment"].shape[0]
print("probability they converted is", proportion_users_converted4)
d. What is the probability that an individual received the new page?
proportion_users_newpage = df2[df2["landing_page"]=="new_page"].shape[0] / df2.shape[0]
print("probability is", proportion_users_newpage)
e. Consider your results from parts (a) through (d) above, and explain below whether you think there is sufficient evidence to conclude that the new treatment page leads to more conversions.

**Answer**: there is no sufficient evidence to conclude that the new treatment page leads to more conversions.
The probability that an individual received the new page is close to 0.5, that means the probability of receiving the new page and the old page are almost tha same.
The probability that the treatment group get converted is also close to the control group (even slightly small), thus the conclusion that new treatment page leads to more conversions has no sufficient evidence.

### Part II - A/B Test Notice that because of the time stamp associated with each event, you could technically run a hypothesis test continuously as each observation was observed. However, then the hard question is do you stop as soon as one page is considered significantly better than another or does it need to happen consistently for a certain amount of time? How long do you run to render a decision that neither page is better than another? These questions are the difficult parts associated with A/B tests in general. `1.` For now, consider you need to make the decision just based on all the data provided. If you want to assume that the old page is better unless the new page proves to be definitely better at a Type I error rate of 5%, what should your null and alternative hypotheses be? You can state your hypothesis in terms of words or in terms of **$p_{old}$** and **$p_{new}$**, which are the converted rates for the old and new pages.

**Answer**:  

<center>$H_{0}$: $p_{old}$ - $p_{new}$ >= 0 or $H_{0}$: $p_{new}$ - $p_{old}$ <= 0<center>  
  
<center>$H_{1}$: $p_{old}$ - $p_{new}$ < 0 or $H_{0}$: $p_{new}$ - $p_{old}$ > 0<center>

`2.` Assume under the null hypothesis, $p_{new}$ and $p_{old}$ both have "true" success rates equal to the **converted** success rate regardless of page - that is $p_{new}$ and $p_{old}$ are equal. Furthermore, assume they are equal to the **converted** rate in **ab_data.csv** regardless of the page.

Use a sample size for each page equal to the ones in **ab_data.csv**.

Perform the sampling distribution for the difference in **converted** between the two pages over 10,000 iterations of calculating an estimate from the null.

Use the cells below to provide the necessary parts of this simulation. If this doesn't make complete sense right now, don't worry - you are going to work through the problems below to complete this problem. You can use **Quiz 5** in the classroom to make sure you are on the right track.
a. What is the **conversion rate** for $p_{new}$ under the null?

outputs.name: stdout
text: conversion rate for 𝑝𝑛𝑒𝑤 under the null is 0.11959708724499628

source: p_new = df2[df2["converted"]==1].shape[0] / df2.shape[0]
print("conversion rate for 𝑝𝑛𝑒𝑤 under the null is", p_new)
b. What is the **conversion rate** for $p_{old}$ under the null?

outputs.name: stdout
text: conversion rate for 𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑑 under the null is 0.11959708724499628

source: p_old = df2[df2["converted"]==1].shape[0] / df2.shape[0]
print("conversion rate for 𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑑 under the null is", p_old)
c. What is $n_{new}$, the number of individuals in the treatment group?

outputs.name: stdout
text: the number of individuals in the treatment group is 145310

source: n_new = df2[df2["group"]=="treatment"].shape[0]
print("the number of individuals in the treatment group is", n_new)
d. What is $n_{old}$, the number of individuals in the control group?

outputs.name: stdout
text: the number of individuals in the control group is 145274

source: n_old = df2[df2["group"]=="control"].shape[0]
print("the number of individuals in the control group is", n_old)
e. Simulate $n_{new}$ transactions with a conversion rate of $p_{new}$ under the null.  Store these $n_{new}$ 1's and 0's in **new_page_converted**.
new_page_converted = np.random.choice([0,1],size=n_new,p=[(1-p_new),p_new])
new_page_converted.mean()
f. Simulate $n_{old}$ transactions with a conversion rate of $p_{old}$ under the null.  Store these $n_{old}$ 1's and 0's in **old_page_converted**.
old_page_converted = np.random.choice([0,1],size=n_old,p=[(1-p_old),p_old])
old_page_converted.mean()
g. Find $p_{new}$ - $p_{old}$ for your simulated values from part (e) and (f).
p_new_p_old = new_page_converted.mean() - old_page_converted.mean()
p_new_p_old
h. Create 10,000 $p_{new}$ - $p_{old}$ values using the same simulation process you used in parts (a) through (g) above. Store all 10,000 values in a NumPy array called **p_diffs**.

p_diffs=[]
for _ in range(10000):
    old_page_converted2 = np.random.choice([0,1],size=n_old,p=[(1-p_old),p_old])
    new_page_converted2 = np.random.choice([0,1],size=n_new,p=[(1-p_new),p_new])
    p_diffs.append(new_page_converted2.mean()-old_page_converted2.mean())
p_diffs = np.array(p_diffs)
i. Plot a histogram of the **p_diffs**.  Does this plot look like what you expected?  Use the matching problem in the classroom to assure you fully understand what was computed here.
plt.hist(p_diffs)
j. What proportion of the **p_diffs** are greater than the actual difference observed in **ab_data.csv**?

plt.hist(p_diffs)
plt.axvline(x=proportion_users_converted4 - proportion_users_converted3, color = "red")
(p_diffs > (proportion_users_converted4 - proportion_users_converted3)).mean()

k. Please explain using the vocabulary you've learned in this course what you just computed in part **j.**  What is this value called in scientific studies?  What does this value mean in terms of whether or not there is a difference between the new and old pages?

**Answer**:  
In part **j**, the p-value has been calculated.  
We assume old page is better unless the new page proves to be definitely better at a Type I error rate of 5%, that means if we want to reject the null hypothesis, the p-value should smaller than 0.05.  
The calulated p-value is much larger than 0.05, which means that we cannot reject the null, thus under the null hypothesis there is no difference between the converted rate of new and old pages.

l. We could also use a built-in to achieve similar results.  Though using the built-in might be easier to code, the above portions are a walkthrough of the ideas that are critical to correctly thinking about statistical significance. Fill in the below to calculate the number of conversions for each page, as well as the number of individuals who received each page. Let `n_old` and `n_new` refer the the number of rows associated with the old page and new pages, respectively.

outputs.name: stderr
text:
/opt/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/statsmodels/compat/pandas.py:56: FutureWarning: The pandas.core.datetools module is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. Please use the pandas.tseries module instead.
  from pandas.core import datetools

source:
import statsmodels.api as sm

convert_old = df2[(df2["group"]=="control") & (df2["converted"]==1)].shape[0]
convert_new = df2[(df2["group"]=="treatment") & (df2["converted"]==1)].shape[0]
n_old = df2[df2["group"]=="control"].shape[0]
n_new = df2[df2["group"]=="treatment"].shape[0]

[convert_old, convert_new, n_old, n_new]

m. Now use `stats.proportions_ztest` to compute your test statistic and p-value.  [Here](https://docs.w3cub.com/statsmodels/generated/statsmodels.stats.proportion.proportions_ztest/) is a helpful link on using the built in.
stat, pval = sm.stats.proportions_ztest([convert_new, convert_old], [n_new, n_old], alternative='larger')
[stat, pval]
n. What do the z-score and p-value you computed in the previous question mean for the conversion rates of the old and new pages?  Do they agree with the findings in parts **j.** and **k.**?
**Answer**:
The z-score is the standardized statistic, the p-value is about 0.9 which agrees with the findings in part **j.** From the values of p-value, we can get the similar finding as in part **k**.

### Part III - A regression approach `1.` In this final part, you will see that the result you achieved in the A/B test in Part II above can also be achieved by performing regression.

a. Since each row is either a conversion or no conversion, what type of regression should you be performing in this case?
**Answer**:
This is a either conversion or no conversion problem, Logistic Regression should be used in this case.

b. The goal is to use **statsmodels** to fit the regression model you specified in part **a.** to see if there is a significant difference in conversion based on which page a customer receives. However, you first need to create in df2 a column for the intercept, and create a dummy variable column for which page each user received.  Add an **intercept** column, as well as an **ab_page** column, which is 1 when an individual receives the **treatment** and 0 if **control**.

outputs.name: stderr

df2["intercept"] = 1
df2[["a","ab_page"]] = pd.get_dummies(df2["group"])
df2 = df2.drop(["a"], axis=1)
df2.head()

c. Use **statsmodels** to instantiate your regression model on the two columns you created in part b., then fit the model using the two columns you created in part **b.** to predict whether or not an individual converts.

outputs.name: stdout

Optimization terminated successfully.

source:
from scipy import stats
stats.chisqprob = lambda chisq, df2: stats.chi2.sf(chisq, df2)
mod = sm.Logit(df2["converted"],df2[["intercept","ab_page"]])
res = mod.fit()
d. Provide the summary of your model below, and use it as necessary to answer the following questions.

text/html:
Logit Regression Results

source: res.summary()

e. What is the p-value associated with **ab_page**? Why does it differ from the value you found in **Part II**?

**Hint**: What are the null and alternative hypotheses associated with your regression model, and how do they compare to the null and alternative hypotheses in **Part II**?

**Answer**:
For the regression model, the null and alternative hypotheses are:  
<center>$H_{0}$: $p_{old}$ = $p_{new}$<center>  
  
<center>$H_{1}$: $p_{old}$ $\neq$ $p_{new}$<center>  

The p-value associated with ab_page is 0.19, it differs from the value in **Part II**. That is because in this case, the Logit Regression has been used, and it is based on a two-tailed test other than based on one-sided tests.  
From the p-value 0.19, we cannot reject the null hypothese since 0.19 is larger than 0.05.

f. Now, you are considering other things that might influence whether or not an individual converts.  Discuss why it is a good idea to consider other factors to add into your regression model.  Are there any disadvantages to adding additional terms into your regression model?

**Answer**:  
The factors that can affect the convert rate should be added in the model.  
For example, the time of the day or the personal informations of the users may cause effects on the converts, we should consider these factors.  
The disadvantages may appear when we add some factors that are highly correlated to each other, then these factors will effect the accuracy of the regression model predictions.

g. Now along with testing if the conversion rate changes for different pages, also add an effect based on which country a user lives in. You will need to read in the **countries.csv** dataset and merge together your datasets on the appropriate rows.  [Here](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.join.html) are the docs for joining tables. 

Does it appear that country had an impact on conversion?  Don't forget to create dummy variables for these country columns - **Hint: You will need two columns for the three dummy variables.** Provide the statistical output as well as a written response to answer this question.

text/html:
user_id country
0 834778 UK
1 928468 US
2 822059 UK
3 711597 UK
4 710616 UK

source:
df4[["CA", "UK", "US"]] = pd.get_dummies(df4["country"])
mod2 = sm.Logit(df4["converted"],df4[["intercept","ab_page","CA","UK"]])
res2 = mod2.fit()
res2.summary()
**Conclusions**:

The p-values for the CA or the UK are all larger than 0.05, which means that we cannot reject the null hypothesis. Thus the factors like nationality cannot cause much differences in the conversion. That tells us that the individual factors of country and page cannot significantly affect the conversion.

h. Though you have now looked at the individual factors of country and page on conversion, we would now like to look at an interaction between page and country to see if there significant effects on conversion.  Create the necessary additional columns, and fit the new model.  

Provide the summary results, and your conclusions based on the results.

source:
# Add the interaction between page and country
df4["CA_PAGE"] = df4["CA"] * df4["ab_page"]
df4["UK_PAGE"] = df4["UK"] * df4["ab_page"]
df4["US_PAGE"] = df4["US"] * df4["ab_page"]
df4.head()

mod3 = sm.Logit(df4["converted"],df4[["intercept","ab_page","CA","UK","CA_PAGE","UK_PAGE"]])
res3 = mod3.fit()
res3.summary()

**Conclusions**:
The p-values for the UK_PAGE or the US_PAGE are all larger than 0.05, which means that we also cannot reject the null hypothesis.   
That tells us that interaction between page and country also cannot significantly affect the conversion.
